revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Neighborhoods of Zagreb to [[:Category:Neighbourhoods of Zagreb]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2016 December 20]].
/* top */ fluency / clarification - By capturing . . onto its surface . . SLMDs can [ . . an SLMD can . .
revision.text:
[[File:SLMD image.png|thumb|Researcher holding SLMD]]
A '''stabilized liquid membrane device''' or '''SLMD''' is a type of [[Environmental monitoring|passive sampling device]] which allows for the [[In situ|in situ]], integrative collection of waterborne, [[Lability|labile]] ionic metal contaminants.<ref name=a1>Brumbaugh, W.G., Petty, J.D., Huckins, J.N., Manahan, S.E. 2002. Stabilized liquid membrane device (SLMD) for the passive, integrative sampling of labile metals in water. Water, Air, Soil Pollut. 133, 109–119.</ref> By capturing and sequestering metal ions onto its surface continuously over a period of days to weeks, an SLMD can provide an integrative measurement of [[Bioavailability|bioavailable]] toxic metal ions present in the aqueous environment.<ref name=a5>Petty, J.D., Brumbaugh, W.G., Huckins, T.W.M., Wiedmeyer, R. 2001. US Patent No. US006296760B1.</ref> As such, they have been used in conjunction with other passive samplers in ecological field studies.<ref name=a4>2012. Potential Causes for Impairment of Rainbow Trout Early Life stages and Loss of Benthic Biodiversity in Indian Creek. Washington State Department of Ecology.</ref><ref name=a7>Brumbaugh, W.G., May, W.T., Besser, J.M., Allert, A.L., Schmitt, C.J. 2008. Assessment of Elemental Concentrations in Streams of the New Lead Belt in Southeastern Missouri, 2002-05. Scientific Investigations Report 2007-5057.</ref>
== Background == Passive samplers were first developed in the early 1970s to monitor concentrations of airborne contaminants industrial workers might be exposed to, but by the 1990s researchers had developed and utilized passive samplers to monitor contaminants in the aqueous environment.<ref name=a2>Alvarez, D. 2013. Development of Semipermeable Membrane Devices (SPMDs) and Polar Organic Integrative Samplers (POCIS) for Environmental Monitoring. Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry. 23: 2179–2181.</ref> The first type of passive sampler made for use in the aqueous environment was the [[Semipermeable membrane devices|semipermeable membrane device]] (SPMD).<ref name=a2></ref> SPMDs could be used to determine time-weighted average concentrations of [[Hydrophobe|hydrophobic]] organic contaminants, but until the early 2000s passive sampling devices for metal contaminants had not yet emerged.<ref name=a1></ref> Metals in the environment can speciate into different forms. Most metals dissolved in the aqueous environment are present as any of several ionic, complex-ion, and organically bound states.<ref name=a1></ref> For most toxic metals, bioavailability is greatest for labile metals in their free ionic state.<ref name=a1></ref> Recognizing the potential usefulness of a passive sampling device that could be used to measure trace amounts of bioavailable toxic metals, researchers at the [[United States Geological Survey]] (USGS) and [[University of Missouri-Columbia]] began development on a counterpart to SPMDs that could be used to sample for labile metals.<ref name=a5></ref>
== Structure and function == The outer portion of a SLMD consists of a section of sealed, flat, semi-permeable polyethylene tubing. Sealed inside this tubing is a 1:1 mixture of a hydrophobic [[Chelation|metal complexing agent]] and a long chain [[Organic acid|organic acid]].<ref name=a1></ref> The organic acid diffuses through the tubing to the outer surface, where the [[carboxylic acid]] portion can form stable complexes with calcium and magnesium ions in the water.<ref name=a5></ref> This allows a waxy layer to slowly accumulate on the outside of the tube. the metal complexing agent continuously mobilizes into this waxy layer, where it can sequester metal ions from the water.<ref name=a1></ref> The hydrophobic metal complexing agent most commonly used in SLMDs is an [[Alkylation|alkylated]] 8-hyroxyquinoline.<ref name=a5></ref> [[Oleic acid]] is commonly used as the other half of the 1:1 hydrophobic reagent mixture, as it readily forms calcium oleates in the aqueous sampling media.<ref name=a1></ref> In addition to the base device, hydrophobic plastic sheaths are sometimes used to house SLMDs in the field.<ref name=a1></ref><ref name=a5></ref> Variable water flow can alter the sampling rates of metals by SLMDs, making a time-averaged concentration difficult to determine.<ref name=a5></ref> By allowing liable metal analytes to diffuse to the SLMD's surface while limiting the diffusion of particulate, [[colloidal]], or humic substances, these hydrophobic sheaths help reduce variability of SLMD uptake in faster moving waters.<ref name=a5></ref>
After being deployed for a known time interval, SLMDs can be recovered from the field for analysis. Washing with 20% [[nitric acid]] allows for the extraction of accumulated metals, and by using analytical techniques like [[Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry|inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy]] (ICP-MS) or [[Atomic absorption spectroscopy|atomic absorption spectroscopy]] (flame AAS) to measure the concentration of metal in the extract, the amount of metal accumulated by the SLMD can be determined.<ref name=a1></ref>
== Applications == SLMDs are known to accumulate [[cadmium]], [[cobalt]], [[copper]], [[nickel]], [[lead]], and [[zinc]],<ref name=a1></ref><ref name=a5></ref> and have been deployed in freshwater monitoring studies by The Washington State Department of Ecology (Ecology)<ref name=a4></ref> and the USGS.<ref name=a6>United States Geological Society (USGS) Columbia Environmental Research Center. May 2004. Retrieved 5/28/2018.</ref> Ecology deployed SLMDs in upper and lower Indian Creek for 28 and 27 days respectively.<ref name=a4></ref> Metal concentrations on the SLMDs were used to estimate the true concentration of metals in the creek. The estimated concentration was expressed as a range based on sampling rate of SLMDs as well as the length of exposure. The purpose of the sampling was to investigate potential causes of sublethal effects of young trout and loss of benthic biodiversity in the creek.<ref name=a4></ref>
== Advantages and limitations == Toxic metals can be present in the aqueous environment at [[Trace element|trace]] or ultra-trace concentrations, yet still be toxicologically significant and thus cause harm to humans or the environment.<ref name=a5></ref> Because these concentrations are so low, they would fall beyond the [[detection limit]]s of most analytical instruments if the media had been sampled using traditional grab samples.<ref name=a3>Petty, J.D., Huckins, J.N. Alvarez, D.A., Brumbaugh, W.G., Cranor W.L., Gale, R.W., Rastall, A.C., Jones-Lepp T.L., Leiker T.J., Rostad C.E., Furlong E.T., 2004. A holistic passive integrative sampling approach for assessing the presence and potential impacts of waterborne environmental contaminants. Chemosphere 54, 695-709.</ref> Using SLMDs to passively collect metals over an extended period of time allows for trace metals to accumulate to detectable levels, which can give more accurate estimate of aquatic chemistry and contamination.<ref name=a5></ref> SLMDs also have the advantage of being able to capture pulses of metal contamination that might otherwise go undetected when using [[Grab sample|grab samples]].<ref name=a4></ref> SLMDs are limited to the assessment of labile metals, and cannot be used to monitor for [[Organic compound|organic contaminants]]. Further, while the ability of SLMDs to sample copper, zinc, nickel, lead, and cadmium has been repeatedly demonstrated,<ref name=a1></ref><ref name=a5></ref><ref name=a7></ref> there has been little laboratory research on their ability to reliably uptake other toxic metals. Still, while laboratory studies on the effectiveness of SLMDs have only investigated copper, zinc, nickel, lead, and cadmium, SLMDs have been used with success in field studies to assess a wider range of metals.<ref name=a4></ref>
== See also ==
* [[Semipermeable membrane devices]] * [[Polar organic chemical integrative sampler]] * [[Diffusive gradients in thin films]] * [[Chemcatcher]]
== References == <references />
[[Category:Environmental monitoring]] [[Category:Environmental science]] [[Category:Analytical chemistry]]

'''Dr. Steve Chase''' is the director of the Advocacy for Social Justice and Sustainability program in the department of Environmental Studies at [[Antioch University New England]]. He is an [[activist]], organizer, [[Quakers|Quaker]], lecturer, and editor.
==Biography== Steve Chase attended the [[Metropolitan State University]] in [[Minneapolis]]. He participated in a program of self-designed study, focusing on [[writing]], [[publishing]], social and ecological issues, and non-profit organizational management. Chase earned an [[Master of Science|MS]] in Environmental Studies came from [[Antioch University New England]] in May 1996. He became the Director of Antioch's Advocacy for Social Justice and Sustainability program (Formerly called the Environmental Advocacy And Organizing program), which he helped found, and used as the subject of his Ph.D. dissertation, in July 2002. The dissertation is entitled ''[http://www.antiochne.edu/directory/page.cfm?page_id=230&id=7160014802&Type=Page Activist Training In The Academy]:'' Developing a Master’s Program in Environmental Advocacy and Organizing.'' Chase completed his Ph.D. at Antioch in November 2006.
In 2002-2003, [[Switzer Foundation|The Robert and Patricia Switzer Foundation]] awarded Chase with the Switzer Environmental Leadership Grant, which covered his salary for the first year of the new program. In 2003-2004 Chase received the [[Ella Baker Fellowship]] to support and promote dialog between leaders in the business, academic, and non-profit arenas in the interest of positive social change.
Chase has taught courses in Organizing Social Movements and Campaigns; Corporate Power, Globalization, and Democracy; Organizational Leadership in the Nonprofit World; and Environmental Justice in the Mississippi Delta.
Steve Chase was the guest editor for [[Orion magazine]]'s Autumn 1996 issue on the theme of ''Nature and Justice''. He has been published in The Trumpeter, [[Whole Terrain]], [[Z Magazine]], [[Terrain.org|Terra Nova]], [[Race, Poverty, and Environment]], [[Environment, Place, and Ethics]], and [[The Journal of Multicultural Environmental Education]]. ''The Environmental Justice Reader: Politics, Poetics, & Pedagogy'' ([[University of Arizona]] Press, 2002 {{ISBN|0-8165-2207-3}}) included his essay ''Changing the Nature of Environmental Studies: Teaching Environmental Justice to 'Mainstream' Students.' ''
Chase is a member of the [[National Organizers Alliance]], and [[United for a Fair Economy]]'s National Trainers Network. He coordinates the [[Pacifica Radio]] Programming Committee at [[WKNH]] Radio in Keene and moderates a [[listserve]] for the annual [[National Training for Trainers in Human Rights Education]]. He has previously served on the editorial boards of [[Orion magazine]], [[Terrain.org|Terra Nova]], [[South End Press]], and [[More Than Money Journal]]. From 1985 to 1988, Chase worked as the business and marketing manager at [[Milkweed Editions]]. He has served on the boards of the [[Underground Railway Theater]], and [[Bookslinger, Inc]]. He worked for the [[Green Party (United States)|Green Party]] from 1984 to 1986, helped co-found [[Men Against Rape and Sexism]] (MARS) in 1980, and was a shop steward for the [[International Typographical Union]], Local 9, in 1984.
==Books== * Chase, Steve, ed. ''Defending the Earth: A Dialogue Between Murray Bookchin and Dave Forman.'' ([[South End Press]], 1990) {{ISBN|0-89608-383-7}} * Chase, Steve. ''Letters to a Fellow Seeker.'' (Philadelphia, PA : QuakerPress of [[Friends General Conference|FGC]], 2012) {{ISBN|1-937768-02-3}}
==References== * [http://www.environmentalprograms.net/guidance/steve-chase/ EnvironmentalPrograms.net Interview with Steve Chase] * Robert and Patricia Switzer Foundation [https://web.archive.org/web/20070928094148/http://www.switzernetwork.org/leadership-samples.html Environmental Programs] *[http://www.antiochne.edu/employeedirectory/steven-chase/ Steve Chase's] Antioch Webpage
==External links== {{wikiquote}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061005222959/http://www.mindfully.org/Reform/2005/Willie-Fontenot-Action-Alert11apr05.htm Action Alert: Willie Fonenot] by Steve Chase, April 11, 2005 * [http://www.antiochne.edu/directory/page.cfm?page_id=230&id=7160014802&Type=Page Activist Training In The Academy], PhD [[Dissertation]] by Chase * El Paso NPR 88.5 [http://www.ktep.org/files/archive_463.ram Interview with Chase on Activist Training]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, April 22, 2007 * [http://ellabakercenter.org Ella Baker Center for Human Rights] * [http://www.environmentalprograms.net/guidance/env-advocacy/ Environmental Advocacy: Academic Requirements, Professional Outlook] published on EnvironmentalPrograms.net - August 1, 2003 * [http://www.antiochne.edu/es/eao/ Environmental Advocacy and Organizing Program] at Antioch * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060901090238/http://comm-org.wisc.edu/pipermail/colist/2005-May/003842.html Take Action for Willie Fontenot], letters include one by Chase * [http://eaop-blog.blogspot.com/ The Well-Trained Activist Blog] maintained by Chase * [http://www.wholeterrain.org/bio.cfm?Contributor_ID=153 Whole Terrain] link to Chase articles published in [[Whole Terrain]]

[[File:Swaziland, administrative divisions - Nmbrs - monochrome.svg|thumb|150px|Administrative divisions of Swaziland
1 - Hhohho
2 - Manzini
3 - Lubombo
4 - Shiselweni]] {{main|Regions of Eswatini}} Eswatini is divided into four regions: * [[Hhohho Region|Hhohho]] * [[Lubombo Region|Lubombo]] * [[Manzini Region|Manzini]] * [[Shiselweni Region|Shiselweni]] Each region is further divided into [[tinkhundla]]. There are 55 tinkhundla in Swaziland and each elects one representative to the [[House of Assembly of Swaziland]]. Tinkhundla are, in turn, divided into smaller [[Umphakatsi|imiphakatsi]]. {{Regions and Tinkhundla of Swaziland}} {{Africa topic|Subdivisions of}} [[Category:Country subdivisions by country|Swaziland]] [[Category:Subdivisions of Eswatini| ]] [[Category:Country subdivisions in Africa|Swaziland]]

{{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=May 2017}} {{one source|date=May 2017}} {{original research|date=May 2017}} {{cleanup|reason=Sole reference is dead.|date=May 2017}} }} {{Infobox military person |name = Thomas D. Waldhauser |image = WALDHAUSER AFRICOM 3.jpg |caption= |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1953|12|16}} |birth_place=[[South St. Paul, Minnesota]], United States |death_place= |nickname= |allegiance = {{flag|United States}} |branch = {{flag|United States Marine Corps}} |serviceyears = 1976 – present |rank = [[File:US Marine 10 shoulderboard.svg|25px]] [[General (United States)|General]] |commands= [[United States Africa Command]] |battles= [[Operation Desert Storm]]
[[Operation Iraqi Freedom]]
[[Operation Enduring Freedom]] |awards = [[Defense Distinguished Service Medal]] (2)
[[Defense Superior Service Medal]] (2)
[[Legion of Merit]] for [[Valor device|Valor]] |laterwork= }} '''Thomas David "Tom" Waldhauser''' (born December 16, 1953) is a [[United States Marine Corps]] general who is the Commander of [[United States Africa Command]]. He previously served as Director for Joint Force Development, J7 on the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Commanding General, I Marine Expeditionary Force, and Commanding General, U.S. Marine Corps Forces Central Command. Waldhauser is an alumnus of Bemidji State University.{{cite web |url=http://www.jcs.mil/Leadership/ArticleView/tabid/3893/Article/572011/lieutenant-general-thomas-d-waldhauser.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-02-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160225101637/http://www.jcs.mil/Leadership/ArticleView/tabid/3893/Article/572011/lieutenant-general-thomas-d-waldhauser.aspx |archivedate=2016-02-25 |df= }} ==Career== General Waldhauser was born in [[South St. Paul, Minnesota]], and is a graduate of [[Bemidji State University]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.bsualumni.org/alumni/alumni/outstanding-alumni-brigadier-general-thomas-waldhauser-2003|title=Outstanding Alumni - 2003|last=|first=|date=|website=Bemidji State University|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}. He was commissioned in 1976 as an infantry officer through [[Platoon Leaders Class]] program via [[Officer Candidates School (United States Marine Corps)|Officer Candidates School]]. His company grade assignments included platoon and company commander billets with both the 1st and 2nd Marine Divisions; Commanding Officer of the [[Marine Detachment]] aboard the [[USS Long Beach (CGN-9)|USS Long Beach]] (CGN-9); and staff of the Commander of [[Amphibious Squadron Seven]]. As a field grade officer, General Waldhauser was a [[Battalion Landing Team]] Operations Officer and served on the faculty of the [[Amphibious Warfare School]]. During the Amphibious Warfare School tour, he deployed to the staff of the Commander, U.S. Marine Corps Central Command (Forward) during [[Gulf War|Operation Desert Shield/Desert Storm]]. General Waldhauser also served on the [[II Marine Expeditionary Force]] staff. He was the Battalion Landing Team Commander of [[3rd Battalion 2nd Marines|3rd Battalion, 2nd Marine Regiment]]. He also had duty at Headquarters, U.S. Marine Corps, and the Pentagon with the Joint Staff Combating Terrorism Directorate (J-34). As a Colonel, General Waldhauser assumed command of the [[15th Marine Expeditionary Unit|15th MEU (SOC)]] in 2000. During this tour, the 15th MEU (SOC) participated in combat operations in Southern Afghanistan for [[Operation Enduring Freedom]] and in Iraq for [[Operation Iraqui Freedom|Operation Iraqi Freedom]]. Appointed to the rank of Brigadier General in 2003, his initial assignments as a General Officer were Commanding General, Marine Corps Warfighting Laboratory, and Deputy Commander, [[Marine Corps Combat Development Command]]. From 2006-2007, he served as Chief of Staff, [[United States Special Operations Command|US Special Operations Command]], in Tampa, Florida. As a Major General, he commanded the [[1st Marine Division (United States)|First Marine Division]] from September 2007 until July 2009. Promoted to Lieutenant General in 2009, General Waldhauser served as the Deputy Commandant for Plans Policies, and Operations during 2009-2010. From October 2010 through September 2012, he served as the Commanding General, [[I Marine Expeditionary Force]], and Commanding General, [[United States Marine Forces Central Command]]. Lieutenant General Waldhauser served as the Senior Military Assistant to the Secretary of Defense from October 2012 through September 2013. General Waldhauser was promoted on 18 July 2016 and became the Commander of US Africa Command in Stuttgart, Germany. General Waldhauser has attended [[Ranger School|U.S. Army Ranger School]], [[United States Army Jumpmaster School|Jumpmaster School]], Amphibious Warfare School, [[Marine Corps Command and Staff College]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.defense.gov/About/Biographies/Biography-View/Article/1324681/general-thomas-d-waldhauser/|title=General Thomas D. Waldhauser > U.S. DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE > Biography View|website=www.defense.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-01}} ==Awards and decorations== General Waldhauser's decorations and medals include:

revision.text:
{{Infobox mountain | name = Toubkal
توبقال
{{small|ⵜⵓⴱⴽⴰⵍ}} | photo = Tizi'n'Toubkal.jpg | photo_caption = ''Tizi-n-Tubkal'' from the summit ridge | photo_size = 300 | elevation_m = 4167 | prominence_m = 3755 | prominence_ref = [http://peaklist.org/WWlists/ultras/africa.html "Africa Ultra-Prominences"] Peaklist.org. Retrieved 2012-01-14.
[[List of peaks by prominence|Ranked 36th]] | map = Morocco | map_caption = | map_size = 300 | label = Toubkal | label_position = right | listing = [[List of countries by highest point|Country high point]]
[[List of Ultras of Africa]] | location = [[Morocco]] | range = [[Atlas Mountains]] | coordinates = {{coord|31|03|33|N|7|54|57|W|type:mountain_scale:100000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | topo = Toubkal Massif Map and Guide{{cite map |publisher = EWP and West Col Productions |title = Toubkal Massif Map and Guide |url = |edition = 1st |year = 2008 |cartography= EWP |scale = 1:160,000 with mountaineering information |series = High Atlas Mountains |isbn = 978-0-906227-98-5 }} | type = | age = | first_ascent = 12 June 1923 by the Marquis de Segonzac, V. Berger, and H. Dolbeau | easiest_route = South [[Cirque|cwm]] (hike in summer) }} '''Toubkal''' or '''Tubkal''' ([[Berber language|Berber]]: ⵜⵓⴳⴳ ⴽⴰⵍ ''Tugg kal''; {{lang-ar|توبقال}} ''Tūbqāl'') is a [[mountain]] peak in southwestern [[Morocco]], located in the [[Toubkal National Park]]. At {{convert|4167|m|ft|0}}, it is the highest peak in the [[Atlas Mountains]], [[Morocco]], [[North Africa]] and the [[Arab World]]. It is an [[ultra prominent peak]], the highest for over 2000 km, located 63 km south of the city of [[Marrakesh]], and a popular destination for climbers. ==Tourism== {{see also|Tourism in Morocco}} [[Image:Atlas Mountains snow cover.jpg|thumb|left|The highest peak of Toubkal]] The first recorded ascent was on 12 June 1923 by the Marquis de Segonzac, Vincent Berger and Hubert Dolbeau, but the mountain may have been climbed before that date.Robin G. Collomb, ''Atlas Mountains'', Goring: West Col, 1980 Trekkers usually approach the mountain from the road-end village of [[Imlil, Atlas Mountains|Imlil]]. Qualified guides can be hired, as well as porters, to carry equipment and food supplies higher into the mountains. For experienced mountaineers, guides are not required for the normal route, as it is a moderate hike and orientation is not a problem. The normal route starts with an easy walk to the village of [[Aroumd]]. Past Aroumd a [[floodplain]] is crossed and the route follows the left slope of the valley southwards. The valley bends to the east to the tiny settlement of Sidi Chamharouch, which has grown around a Muslim shrine. At Sidi Chamharouch, the path leads over the stream and runs steeply uphill to the right side of the Isougouane valley, which leads to two stone-built refuges (old Neltner Refuge and new Refuge du Toubkal) that are often used as base camp at {{convert|3207|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}. It is possible to buy good meals in the Refuge du Toubkal. Tents can be pitched near the refuges for a small charge. From that point a path crosses the stream, climbs a steep [[scree]] slope to the east and enters a valley ([[Cirque|corrie]]), then climbs another steep slope to reach a [[Mountain pass|col]] (Tizi'n'Toubkal at 3,940m). At the col the route turns left (northwards) to the summit ridge of Jbel Toubkal. The 4,167m summit is crowned with a curious pyramidal metal frame and views take in most of the Atlas and [[Little Atlas]] Mountains. The ascent during the summer (from May) is non-technical yet moderately difficult, only complicated by steep and slippery scree slopes and [[altitude sickness]]. Sturdy boots and proper (windproof) clothing are required, and [[trekking poles]] are helpful on the scree. An [[Ice axe|ice-axe]] may be needed on the remaining snowfields in the early summer. The ascent during the end of the winter and spring (February/March) is more difficult. [[Crampons]] are necessary to ascend through the snow and - in some cases - ice. It is possible to climb the mountain in two days - first day up to the refuge (around seven hours), second day to the summit (around five hours) and back to Imlil (up to five hours). In summer the mountains can be very dry, but are sometimes subject to storms. Although the temperature should remain above zero during the day, freezing conditions are possible over 3,500m. In winter the mountains are covered in snow and ice, and can be prone to avalanches. Skiing is possible as the snow can lie to considerable depth and cover many rocky slopes. Information about the state of the route can be obtained at Marrakech tourist offices or at Imlil. {{Wide image|Jebel Toubkal summit panorama.jpg|1000px|
360 degree panorama from the summit
|alignment|alt=alt text}} {{clear|left}} ==Gallery== Image:Birds and toubkal.jpg|[[Bird]]s soaring above the path to the summit Image:Mittelholzer-toubkal.jpg|Jbel Toubkal in December 1930. Air photo taken by Swiss pilot and photographer [[Walter Mittelholzer]]. File:Atlas Mountains, Hiking.jpg|Hikers midway to the summit File:Hiker on toubkal.jpg|Hiker on toubkal File:Toubkal mountain.jpg|Spring water near the summit == See also == * Nearby villages of [[Asni]], [[Ikkiss]], [[Imlil, Atlas Mountains|Imlil]] and [[Tacheddirt]]. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{commons category}} {{Wikivoyage|Jebel Toubkal}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100420002630/http://www.imlil.org/Toubkal.htm Routes up Mount Toubkal] * [http://www.summitpost.org/show/mountain_link.pl/mountain_id/50 Summitpost.org page about Jbel Toubkal] * [http://www.caingram.info/Toubkal.htm Photo Gallery of Jebel Toubkal and the High Atlas] * [http://www.imlil.org/toubkal_refuges.htm Refuge information] * [http://nikopav.blogspot.co.uk/2017/12/climbing-toubkal.html Useful information on climbing Toubkal] {{Mountains of Morocco}} [[Category:Mountains of Morocco]] [[Category:Atlas Mountains]] [[Category:Geography of Marrakesh-Safi]] [[Category:Highest points of countries]] [[Category:Four-thousanders of Africa]]

{{unreferenced|date=April 2014}} '''The Tricity''' is an area of Nepal that comprises the cities of [[Baglung]], [[Beni, Dhawalagiri|Beni]] and [[Kushma]] as core market centers. The three cities are headquarters of Myagdi, Baglung and Parbat districts respectively. [[Baglung]] also happens to be the headquarters of Dhaulagiri zone. The Trinity area is a major center of population and economic activity in West-central Nepal. As three district headquarters and the zonal headquarter are located in the valley there is a large concentration of governmental and nongovernmental offices, banks, educational institutes, cottage industries and healthcare centers. Geographically, 50 km long, region of [[Kali Gandaki]] valley stretching from Galeshwor to the north to Phalewas to the south can be considered the Tricity region.
[[Category:Geography of Nepal]]

page.title: UCL Centre for Advanced Spatial Analysis

revision.text:
<!-- Do not remove this line! --> <!-- Do not remove this line! --> The '''Centre for Advanced Spatial Analysis''' (CASA) is a research centre at [[University College London]] (UCL) which specialises in the application and visualisation of [[Spatial analysis|spatial analytic]] techniques and simulation models to cities and regions.
== History ==
CASA was established in 1995 by a group of UCL academics who wanted a focus for their research across different academic departments in the field of [[geographic information system]]s (GIS). [[Michael Batty]] was appointed the first director and initially held a joint appointment as Professor of Spatial Analysis and Planning in the Departments of Geography and [[The Bartlett]] School of Planning. He is now Chairman of the Centre. In 2000, Paul Longley was appointed Deputy Director and Professor of Geographic Information Science. He now directs UCL's ESRC Consumer Data Research Centre (CDRC).<ref>[http://www.ucl.ac.uk/news/news-articles/0214/06022014ucl-big-data UCL and Big Data: Funding announcement] (dated 6 February 2014). Accessed 6 July 2014.</ref> CASA is still largely funded through research grants but from 2010 it began to diversify, introducing Masters programmes in spatial analysis and in Smart Cities. Professor Andrew Hudson-Smith took over the directorship in 2011 and appointed a Deputy Director, Dr Adam Dennet, in 2016. The Masters courses developed since 2010 include the [http://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/casa/programmes/postgraduate/msc-smart-cities-and-urban-analytics MSc in Smart Cities and Urban Analytics] and the [http://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/casa/programmes/postgraduate/mres-spatial-data-science-visualisation MRes in Data Science and Visualisation]. It currently has 6 lecturers and 2 teaching fellows leading its courses. Sir [[Alan Wilson (academic)|Alan Wilson]] was appointed Professor of Urban and Regional Systems in 2008. The Centre is now an administrative unit in [[The Bartlett]] School which is the Faculty of the Built Environment.
== Research areas ==
CASA researches the science of cities, working with city governments and related research groups on simulating and visualising urban problems. Their work on transport and movement has included [[Transport for London]]’s [[Oyster card]] data,<ref>[http://www.economist.com/node/21558604 London’s Tube and big data: Underground movement] ''The Economist'' 14 July 2012</ref> public bikes schemes such as the [[Santander Cycles|London's cycle hire scheme]],<ref>Hussey, Matt, [https://www.wired.co.uk/magazine/archive/2011/04/start/bike-routes-for-a-city-with-no-tube Boris-bike routes for a city with no Tube], ''Wired Magazine'' 2 March 2011 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141103122059/http://www.wired.co.uk/magazine/archive/2011/04/start/bike-routes-for-a-city-with-no-tube |date=3 November 2014 }}</ref> population segregation in large cities<ref>Pickford, James and Giles, Chris (2012), [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/c83d643a-d4a3-11e1-bb88-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2HUmWjQnM London: The world in a city], ''Financial Times'', 23 July 2012</ref> as well as climate change in the London region.<ref>[http://www.planningresource.co.uk/article/913745/centre-extends-science-planning Centre extends science of planning], ''Planning Resource'', 19 June 2009</ref> The centre is active in exploring how the [[Internet of Things]] can be deployed in large urban areas linking objects in the built environment through internet technologies,<ref>Cookson, Clive (2011) [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/693a21d6-dedf-11e0-9130-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1Y0mtNtZF ’Internet of things’ is set to come], ''Financial Times'', 14 September 2011</ref> and was active with the [[Technology Strategy Board]]’s Future Cities [[Catapult centres|Catapult]] in pioneering new software systems for smart cities such as dashboards and portals.<ref>Dean, Will (2012) [https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/features/will-deans-ideas-factory-everything-you-wanted-to-know-about-your-city-7729082.html Will Dean's Ideas Factory: Everything you wanted to know about your city], ''The Independent'', 10 May 2012</ref> Its research programme in city science concentrates on applying social physics to urban systems based on modelling the diffusion of behaviours such as the [[2011 England riots|2011 London riots]]<ref>Geere, Duncan (2012) [https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2012-04/20/earlier-response-shorten-london-riots Model suggests earlier response could have shortened London riots], ''Wired Magazine'', 20 April 2012</ref> and it is heavily involved in using methods of scaling and [[allometry]] to examine city performance.<ref>[http://www.economist.com/node/21557313 The laws of the city], ''The Economist'', 21 June 21, 2012</ref>
== Research programme ==
CASA’s research programme is primarily funded by research grants from the [[RCUK|British research councils]], mainly [[ESRC]] and [[EPSRC]]. Since 2008, the centre has been increasingly funded by EU research grants from the 7th Framework and from the [[European Research Council]] (ERC) and in 2014, it was awarded funding from the [[Technology Strategy Board]]'s Future Cities Catapult <ref>[https://futurecities.catapult.org.uk "Future Cities Catapult"]</ref> to provide demonstration capabilities for urban and regional modelling.
CASA has graduated some 41 PhDs since 2000. Several alumni have made important contributions to the science of cities working in geographic information systems, spatial analysis and urban modelling at UC Berkeley, Maryland, George Mason, UCL, KRISH, LSE, TU-Istanbul, KCL, Cardiff, Tehran, Manchester, OU, ETH-Zurich, Kingston, Malta, Warwick, Birkbeck, and Liverpool. [[OpenStreetMap]] (OSM) originated in UCL CASA and The Bartlett, and the firms GeoFutures<ref>[http://www.geofutures.com/ "GeoFutures"]</ref> and Intelligent Space (acquired by [[Atkins (company)|Atkins]]) were associated with the centre. The company Prospective Labs spun-off from CASA in 2016 and is engaged on developing new software systems for planning and land management.
== Contributions ==
Members of CASA have pioneered the development of urban and regional modelling through a series of books that go back to the 1970s. Their work is published in a series of web sites on the CASA Blog Aggregator.<ref>[http://www.blogs.casa.ucl.ac.uk/ "The CASA Blog Aggregator"]</ref> Key works that reflect CASA’s research programme are ''Fractal Cities'' (1994),<ref>Michael Batty & Paul Longley (1994) [http://www.fractalcities.org/ ''Fractal Cities: A Geometry of Form and Function''] (Academic Press, San Diego, CA and London)</ref> ''Cities and Complexity'' (2005),<ref>Michael Batty (2005) [http://mitpress.mit.edu/books/cities-and-complexity ''Cities and Complexity: Understanding Cities with Cellular Automata, Agent-Based Models, and Fractals''] (MIT Press, Cambridge MA and London)</ref> ''The Science of Cities and Regions'' (2012),<ref>[https://www.springer.com/earth+sciences+and+geography/geography/book/978-94-007-2265-1 ''The Science of Cities and Regions''] (2012)</ref> ''Agent Based Model of Geographical Systems'' (2012),<ref>[https://www.springer.com/social+sciences/population+studies/book/978-90-481-8926-7 ''Agent Based Model of Geographical Systems''] (2012)</ref> and ''The New Science of Cities'' (2013).<ref>[http://mitpress.mit.edu/books/new-science-cities ''The New Science of Cities''] (2013)</ref> The journals ''[[Environment and Planning|Environment and Planning B]]'',<ref>[http://www.envplan.com/B.html ''Environment and Planning B'']</ref> edited by Batty, and ''Future Internet'',<ref>[http://www.mdpi.com/journal/futureinternet ''Future Internet'']</ref> edited by Hudson-Smith, are run from CASA. The major research focus of CASA is in blending the visualisation of complex urban systems with their simulation.
